data.title: Ian Mahinmi Uses â€˜French Dealâ€™ Brand to Connect His Roots, Hip-Hop and Style ğŸ‘”
data.meta_description: Washington Wizards big man Ian Mahinmi has infused his love for his roots, hip-hop and style into his upscale streetwear brand, the French Deal.
data.text:
Growing up in France, Ian Mahinmiâ€˜s introduction to basketball wasnâ€™t through the NBA; rather, the young soccer player first started watching the sport through hoopsâ€™ most authentic digital roots: AND1 Mixtape Tour videos.

The videos didnâ€™t just spark his love for basketball, though. The larger-than-life personalities, street swag and hip-hop influence is where Mahinmi discovered his sense of individuality. Years later, those grainy videos continued to serve as inspiration as Mahinmi became a creative partner for the French Deal clothing brand.

â€œI was addicted to watching AND1 mixtapes. It had the best songs, the best rap, throughout the whole thing,â€ the Wizards big man tells SLAM. â€œTo me, this was the starting point. You get on the court and because youâ€™ve seen how a guy in an AND1 Mixtape was rocking a headband a certain way or a wrist band a certain way, and you want to do the same thing. Thatâ€™s how fashion starts, and thatâ€™s how it started for me. Hip-hop and rap music and R&B, itâ€™s the foundation of French Deal.â€

The French Deal, which Mahinmi has been working on for eight years with stylist Steeven Kodjia and former soccer star Ousmane Dabo, was a calculated risk â€” Mahinmi described it as â€œtaking a leap and hoping something is going to catch you.â€

In a competitive industry, Mahinmi, Kodjia and Dabo decided making that leap was still worthwhile. Combining authentic stories, a belief in organic growth and dedication to quality and self-expression, the French Deal has not only kept its head above water, but grown since its creation. Everything the trio creates is well thought-out with clear intentions.

â€œEverything you do, [all the] clothes, every volume, itâ€™s for a reason, itâ€™s to tell that story,â€ Mahinmi says. â€œHonestly, itâ€™s very organic. To be successful, everything has to be organic. Itâ€™s not like one day you woke up and felt like you wanted to do clothes. Itâ€™s bigger than that. Itâ€™s a part of your story.

â€œFor people to make clothes in general, you make clothes for a reason. You make clothes for your environment. You make clothes because you were inspired by something around you,â€ he adds. â€œWhen we make a shirt that has African roots, itâ€™s for a reason. Itâ€™s because at some point, we wanted to tell the world about this particular African technique.â€

A love for hip-hop was the common ground that led to the launch of the brand and has been the catalyst for creative continuity since.

â€œIâ€™m from a very poor neighborhood, all my partners are, but what we always had was music,â€ Mahinmi explains. â€œWe have the same background and it makes everything so much easier, itâ€™s flowing. So when we talk clothes, we talk the same language.â€

The background goes deeper than just music, however; all three founders have West African roots, grew up in France and spent time out west in the United States.

â€œWeâ€™re so close to our countries and backgrounds and we donâ€™t want to let that go,â€ Mahinmi says. â€œOnce you come to French Deal, we feel like we can educate you, too.â€

When the trio decided to start the brand, they contemplated doing something low-cost, but ultimately decided to go the upscale streetwear route because itâ€™d mean more opportunities to cultivate meaningful, face-to-face relationships with customers. The French Deal is based in Paris, but itâ€™s home base isnâ€™t a store, itâ€™s a home and a showroom.

â€œIf you come to our showroom, you come to my house, you come to my apartment,â€ Mahinmi says. â€œIâ€™m gonna receive you. Youâ€™re coming in, itâ€™s big so we have offices, clothes, we have a kitchen and I can fix you up something to eat, something to drink. Itâ€™s that feeling. Itâ€™s a showroom because itâ€™s home.â€

The personal relationships between brand and consumer mean that any piece from a French Deal volume â€” its alternative to the traditional FW and SS line model â€” can be fully customized. Those wanting to feel like one-of-a-kind can have what they wear reflect that. Mahinmi points out that if thereâ€™s a leather jacket displayed in black and a customer wants it in red, itâ€™ll get done. If a customer wants a pair of pants cut high water, baggy, or any other way, itâ€™s done.

Mahinmi has taken it upon himself to expand his role and knowledge by learning the entire process of what goes into making each piece. Now, he feels a connection to everything the French Deal produces.

â€œEvery single piece we have has a story,â€ he says. â€œSome stuff, the fabrics were made in Africa. We assemble everything in France. Itâ€™s a whole story, the whole storyline is fantastic.

â€œThe relationship you have with fashion should be really personal. You can easily find me in the summer in the market looking for fabrics. Iâ€™m very much interested in the process, too. Itâ€™s more than just being interested in fashion, Iâ€™m interested in the clothes. I love the ideas, the brainstorming. I love the process â€” I almost love the process as much as the finished product.â€

Mahinmi takes such an interest in learning about fashion because itâ€™s a way that he was able to learn about himself, and he knows itâ€™s the same for countless others.

â€œBeing able to express yourself is a huge step in getting to know yourself,â€ he says. â€œSo many people would rather do what everyone else does than pay attention. Once you can dress yourself not caring about how people will judge you outside, thatâ€™s when you really know yourself. when you can walk outside your house feeling great about what you wear because you like it.â€

Just like fashion has allowed Mahinmi to learn more about himself, so has his entrepreneurial journey.

â€œThe industry is hard. Fashion, especially upscale stuff, you have to be solid. You have to be strong,â€ he describes. â€œThereâ€™s definitely rough times. There was times I was like I donâ€™t know if itâ€™s worth doing this anymore. We never gave up, though. We stayed the course, took some losses and kept on growing organically. The journey has been a lot of ups and downs â€¦ itâ€™s hard, but it gives you a new respect.

â€œIâ€™ve seen a whole other side of business I was never exposed to with basketball. That line has helped me grow so much as a businessman, entrepreneur, and human being.â€

And today, at 31 years old, heâ€™s a better man for it. He feels, and looks, his best. Itâ€™s a feeling he wants everyone to have.
